item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. When a bank has excess cash on hand, it can loan it out to another one that needs it. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeOn Wednesday, the Fed is expected to hike interest rates even higher to bring inflation back from levels we haven’t seen in decades. Instead, the central bank adjusts what’s known as the “federal funds rate,” which is the average interest rate that banks pay each other for overnight loans. This week, we’re going to carve out some space to explore interest rate hikes from a variety of angles. The banks lending to each other typically settle on an interest rate near the midpoint of the Fed’s range. Because Fed Chair Jerome Powell doesn’t just show up at your bank and tell them to raise their interest rates. Like, what are the mechanics? What that is: Commercial banks borrow and lend money to each other so that they can meet liquidity requirements set by regulators before the business day begins. You should also know that the Fed picks a range for the federal funds rate—not a specific number. In March, when the Fed hiked interest rates for the first time following the onset of the pandemic, it raised its target range from 0–25 basis points to 25–50.

UNC business professor Jim Kitchen is scheduled to blast off on Blue Origin’s mission to space on Thursday, which might only be the second most exciting part of his week if his beloved Tar Heels beat Duke in the Final Four on Saturday. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeWhen that didn’t pan out, he shifted focus to traveling as a hobby. Kitchen said that, while he’s extremely excited to go up to space for 11 minutes with Blue Origin, his next goal is to view the whole world from space.

The researchers found that companies with business degree-wielding managers don’t see any increase in sales, productivity, investment, or employment compared to companies without business managers. The paper looked at businesses in the US and Denmark and found similar results in both countries: Managers with a business degree oversee declining pay at their businesses.
